instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-10 Works fine until lid is closed
threads.message: Minimal liquid-damage on an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. Booting. There was some corrosion inside the Touch Bar cables that I was able to ultrasonic and get it to come back. The main damage was on the lid sensor. I replaced the capacitor and the pins are measuring correctly in diode mode compared to the right-side sensor. Computer works great until I close the lid. It won't come out of closed mode - the computer is convinced the lid is closed - no keys, no backlight etc. Any ideas where the breakdown might be in the circuit?

threads.message: Probably crap under the sensor or under the sub board. Flux and reflow....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-10 Works fine until lid is closed
threads.message:
Thanks for the tips, I would love to measure <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> and it's pull-up resistors, but have no idea where they are on this board, especially on the accessible side of the board once I install it to test the sensor.

In the end, the sensor just needed some more work. I fluxed and reflowed it as suggested and ran a trace on top of the sensor to make sure those two components were solidly connected and it's working perfectly now. Fixed. Thanks for the tips.
